lines.text: How old do you think I am, anyway?
137 years, Admiral, according to Starfleet records.
Explain how you remember that so exactly!
I remember every fact I am exposed to, sir.

[looking at both sides of Data's head]
I don't see no points on your ears, boy, but you sound like a Vulcan.
No, sir. I am an android.
Hmph. Almost as bad.
I thought it was generally accepted, sir, that Vulcans are an advanced and most honorable race.
They are, they are. And damn annoying at times.
Well, this is a new ship. But she's got the right name. Now, you remember that, you hear?
I will, sir.
You treat her like a lady. And she'll always bring you home.
[last lines]
Some problem, Riker?
Just hoping this isn't the usual way our missions will go, sir.
Oh, no, Number One. I'm sure most will be much more interesting. - Let's see what's out there. Engage!
Do you consider yourself superior to us?
I am superior, sir, in many ways. But I would gladly give it up to be human.
Nice to meet you... Pinocchio.

[seeing a boy standing in the turbolift]
What the hell? Children are not allowed on the bridge!
[Dr. Crusher steps out of the lift]

[... ]
Sir, my son is not on the bridge; he merely accompanied me on the turbolift.

[stunned]
Your son?
His name's Wesley. You last saw him years ago, when...
[she leaves the sentence unfinished]

[understands]
Ah... Well - as long as he's here...

[clears his throat]
I, er... I knew... I knew your father, Wesley.
Isn't it a little presumptuous of a first officer to second-guess his captain's judgment?
Permission to speak candidly, sir?
Always.

Having been a first officer yourself, you know that assuming that responsibility must, by definition, include the safety of the captain. I have no problem with following any rules you lay down, short of compromising your safety.
And you don't intend to back off from that position?
No, sir.
[Worf's first line]
Shields and deflectors up, sir!
[Yar's first line]
Lieutenant Worf is right, sir. As Security Chief, I can't just stand here and let...
[she is interrupted by Picard]
[Yar has suggested to take on the Q vessel]
Lieutenant - are you recommending that we fight a life form that can do all those things?
One further thing - special favor.
Anything, sir.
Using the same strength you showed with Captain DeSoto, I would appreciate it if you could keep me from making an ass of myself with children.
Sir?
I'm not a family man, Riker. And yet, Starfleet has given me a ship with children aboard.
Yes, sir.
And I, er... I don't feel comfortable with children. But since a captain needs an image of genealogy, you're to see that's what I project.
Aye, sir.
Welcome to the Enterprise, Commander Riker.
Captain! The Ferengi would be very interested in a base like this.
Fine. Let's hope they find you as tasty as they did their past associates.
the word... 'snoop'?
Data, how can you be programed as a virtual encyclopedia of human information without knowing a simple word like 'snoop'?
a kind of human behavior I was not designed to emulate.
Prejudice is very human.
And now a personal request, sir. Permission to clean up the bridge.
At least we are acquainted with the judge, Captain.
What do we do now, Captain? With their monitoring our every move and every word?
We do exactly what we'd do if this Q never existed. If we're going to be damned, let's be damned for what we really are.
Would you object to your Captain ordering a clearly illegal kidnapping?
No objection, sir.

[referring to Picard]
He calls that a little adventure?

Space... the Final Frontier. These are the voyages of the Star Ship, 'Enterprise'. Its continuing mission... to see out new worlds. To seek out new life and new civilizations. To boldly go where no one has gone, before.
[Q's first line]
Thou art notified that thy kind hath infiltrated the galaxy too far already. Thou art directed to return to thine own solar system immediately.
we surrender. State that we are not asking for any terms or conditions.
[Beverly Crusher's first line]
Actually, we were about to do some shopping.
[Picard has introduced Riker and Troi to each other]
Have the two of you met before?
We have, sir.
Excellent. I consider it important for my key officers to know each other's abilities.
We do, sir. We do.
Let's see what this Galaxy-class starship can do.
Lieutenant! Do you intend to blast a hole in the viewer?
[when Worf points a phaser at Q who has appeared on the main view screen]
You must return to your world and put an end to the commies. All it takes are a few good men.
You will now answer to the charge of being a grievously savage race.
'Grievously savage' could mean anything. I will answer only specific charges.
Are you certain you want a full disclosure of human ugliness? So be it, fool.
"Kill all the lawyers."
Which was done.
Leading to the rule "Guilty until proven innocent."
Of course. Bringing the innocent to trial would be unfair.
Captain, you may find that you are not nearly clever enough to deal with what lies ahead for you.
Shut off that damn noise! Go to yellow alert!
[when the red alert siren sounds for the first time]
Leave us! We've passed your little test.
Temper, temper, mon Captaine.
Get off my ship!
I do so only because it suits me to leave. But I will not promise never to appear again.
[first lines]

Captain's log, stardate 41153.7 - Our destination is planet Deneb IV, beyond which lies the great, unexplored mass of the galaxy. My orders are to examine Farpoint, a starbase built there by the inhabitants of that world. Meanwhile, I am becoming better acquainted with my new command, this Galaxy-class USS Enterprise. I am still somewhat in awe of its size and complexity. As for my crew, we are short in several key positions, most notably a first officer. But I'm informed that a highly experienced man, one Commander William Riker, will be waiting to join the ship at our Deneb IV destination.
printout message, urgent, all stations on all decks. Prepare for emergency saucer sep. You will command the saucer section, Lieutenant.
I'm a Klingon, sir. For me to seek escape when my Captain goes into battle...
You are a Starfleet officer, Lieutenant!
Aye, sir.
[Wesley Crusher's first line]
Mother! It's Commander Riker.

[about Wesley]
He does seem to have a very good grasp of starship operations.
You've just won his mother's heart, Captain.
Sorry, sir. I seem to be commenting on everything.
Good. Don't stop, my friend.
Captain, if he's not open to evidence in our favor, where will you go from there?
I'll attend to my duty.
To the bitter end?
I see nothing so bitter about that.
[the crew has solved the Farpoint mystery]
I see now, it was too simple a puzzle. Generosity has always been my... weakness.

[to Riker who's rang the door chime for the Ready Room on the Battle Bridge, the first of many times he will say throughout the series]
Come.
You will agree, Data, that Starfleet's orders are difficult.

[Data's first line]
Difficult? Simply solve the mystery of Farpoint Station.
[Troi's first line]
Farpoint Station. Even the name sounds mysterious.
[O'Brien's first line]
All decks acknowledging, sir.
[Riker's first line]

Personal log, Commander William Riker, stardate 41153.7 - The USS Hood has dropped me off at Farpoint Station, where I await the arrival of the new USS Enterprise, to which I have been assigned as First Officer. Meanwhile, I have been asked to visit the Farpoint administrator's office in the old city.
[La Forge's first line]
Sir, the Enterprise is arriving, but...
[Riker interrupts him]
Do we have clearance?
Aye sir, into standard parking orbit.
Make it so.
I can sense only strong emotions, Groppler. I'm only half-Betazoid. My father was a Starfleet officer.
You know anything about Farpoint Station, sir? It sounds like a fairly dull place.
We've heard that we may find it rather interesting.

[of Picard]
He's such a dullard, isn't he?
We've no fear of what the true facts about us will reveal.
Soldiers, you will press those triggers if this criminal answers with any word other than 'guilty'.

[of the space vessel life form]
Captain, that thing was killing my people!
Was there a reason?
It is an unknown, Captain. Isn't that enough?
If you'd earned that uniform you're wearing, you'd know that the unknown is what brings us out here.
Wasted effort considering human intelligence.
